newsitem.title: USA: Alaska governor vetos billboard legislation.
newsitem.headline: Alaska governor vetos billboard legislation.

text.p: Alaska's governor Friday vetoed a controversial bill that would have eased restrictions on roadside signs, saying the law would permit billboards that would mar the state's scenery.

"Since territorial days, Alaska leaders have resisted the urge to clutter our magnificent landscape with billboards, and the state proudly leads the nation in the protection of our unmatched scenery," Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat, said.
Knowles vetoed the legislation in a ceremony at Mendenhall Glacier, a popular tourist destination in the state capital of Juneau.
At the same time he issued his veto, the governor signed new state regulations allowing standardized directional signs within state rights-of-way along the highways.
The bill Knowles vetoed would have allowed directional signs outside of the state rights-of-way strips, and would have reduced the penalty for sign violations.
The bill was passed by the Republican-controlled legislature at the urging of tourism businesses who say the state's billboard restructions hurt them.
Knowles' Republican predecessor, Gov. Walter Hickel, vetoed a similar bill in 1994.
An override vote is scheduled for Monday, and Republican leaders are confident of easily overturning Knowles' action, said a spokesman for the bill's sponsor, Republican state Sen. Lyda Green.
